Traveling the world full-time doesn't solve anything

I’ve been traveling the world full time for a bit more than 4 years. Given the opportunity of working remotely from anywhere, I’ve left my country back in April ’14.

Since the day I've left people come to me asking for a life changing advice on how they can do the same.

They want a change.

Well, guess what. Me too.

Even though I’ve been pretty much changing places every few months or so, I’ve been also looking for a change. I wanted to do things differently and I knew I had to step out of my comfort zone so this could happen.

It’s part of human nature to find a way to make whatever we’re doing feels comfortable — even when it’s something that is not common at the beginning, such as having no fixed address. My comfort zone was on the change itself.

That's why I've decided to spend almost 6 months in a single place. I know, this is nothing for most people in the world and you might be ironically thinking “uhhh, such an adventurous girl!”, but for me it was c r a z y. I was changing places every 2 months over the past few years, so 6 months felt like an eternity.

I was fucking terrified.

Just the thought of going to the same park every single day with my dogs (yes, I travel with two dogs) freaked the fuck out of me. My comfort zone was back there on the road, not watching the trees grow in Palermo. I didn’t know how to live a “normal” life anymore.

“How am I supposed to live SIX LONG MONTHS in a single city? Better yet, a city without a big community of like minded people — or people who could even speak the same language as me?”

After multiple anxiety crisis and flight searches, I realised that this was a form of breaking my own comfort zone once again.

Now that I'm about to get back on the road again, I'm feeling the same as I did in 2014: feeling chills just by thinking about all the places I’m going and freaking excited about it.

Was it pleasant to break out of my comfort zone? No way.

But if we need to change something about ourselves, we need to change something around us as well.

I’m sure I’ve changed A LOT during the past few months.

This made me realise that what makes me feel alive is not the constant travel — nor having a place to call home.

What makes me feel alive is the constant break of habits. It’s kicking my comfort zone in the ass and doing something I’m not used to do.
mongodbDatabaseArticles.title: Traveling the world full-time doesn't solve anything
